docs.lead_paragraph: Lawsuits to overturn the Affordable Care Act are just desperate attempts to do in the courts what Republicans have failed to do in the political arena.
docs.abstract: Editorial criticizes two long-shot lawsuits filed by conservative critics of Pres Obama's health care reform law; holds suits should be recognized as attempts to use courts to scuttle a law that Congressional Republicans have repeatedly tried and fail to repeal; urges Supreme Court to reject arguments in cases outright should they somehow reach the court.
docs.snippet: Lawsuits to overturn the Affordable Care Act are just desperate attempts to do in the courts what Republicans have failed to do in the political arena.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nurse practitioners have long fought against Texas regulations that link them financially and professionally to supervising physicians, a construct they say limits their ability to treat patients in a state with a looming shortage of primary care doctors.

headline.main: Caregivers Struggle to Untie a Confining Knot
headline.print_headline: Caregivers Struggle to Untie a Confining Knot

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress seems frightened of the political fallout that would come from making much-needed cuts in the defense budget.
docs.abstract: Editorial criticizes Congress for failing to make much-needed cuts to a defense budget that nation no longer needs or can afford; argues that House Armed Service Committee remains chained to parochial and business interests; holds that failure undermines the Pentagon's own agenda and will mean less money for newer weapons.
docs.snippet: Congress seems frightened of the political fallout that would come from making much-needed cuts in the defense budget.

docs.lead_paragraph: Overseeing the business of medicine is big business.

headline.main: Medicine’s Top Earners Are Not the M.D.s
headline.print_headline: Doctor’s Salaries Are Not the Big Cost

docs.abstract: News analysis; analysis of base pay of insurance executives, hospital executives and even hospital administrators shows that they are often paid more than doctors; proliferation of high earners in the medical business and administration ranks adds to United States' $3.7 trillion health care bill and stands in stark contrast with other developed countries.
docs.snippet: Overseeing the business of medicine is big business.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study has found that, compared with patients who have private insurance, those on the government health plan arrive in worse shape, suffer more complications and stay longer in the hospital.

headline.main: Poorer Health of Surgery Patients on Medicaid May Alter Law’s Bottom Line
headline.print_headline: Poorer Health of Patients on Medicaid May Raise Costs

docs.abstract: University of Michigan study published in journal JAMA Surgery finds surgery patients covered by Medicaid arrive at the hospital in worse health, experience more complications, stay longer and cost more than patients with private insurance; study may offer preview of what to expect as millions of uninsured people qualify for Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act.
docs.snippet: A new study has found that, compared with patients who have private insurance, those on the government health plan arrive in worse shape, suffer more complications and stay longer in the hospital.
